posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: My team’s Reefscape robot utilized MAXSwerve alongside Vortexes and NEO 550s this season. I’m curious whether there’s a quantifiable limitation specific to MAXSwerve only allowing 550s as turning motors or if there’s a noticeable point where the benefits diminish. Additionally, has anyone successfully modified their modules to use a turning motor that isn’t a 550? We encountered a significant number of issues with these motors this season, making the idea of removing them from future robots a plausible consideration. Any insights or experiences would be greatly appreciated!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A bigger motor will definitely fail less often. There are probably performance costs, too, but I don’t think they’re massive.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: We just finished our third season with MAX swerve. Yes, NEO 550s are small and have issues, especially with their fragile encoder cables. We're considering switching to CTR Electronics, which would require a custom adapter, or moving to Mark 4i instead. I'll update this thread if we decide to develop a Minion adapter.

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: Completely switching over to a different swerve system is what I want to do, but the cost involved is no small feat, especially after investing as much as we have in MaxSwerve. I’m considering working on an adapter to use a regular NEO since we have a bunch of those lying around.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: What issues in particular are you having? I’ve found 550s to be pretty reliable. Just be careful with the encoder cable, and maybe a touch of hot glue on the CAN bus connectors on the Spark Max. To unplug the encoder cable, I usually use a small flathead screwdriver to kinda lever out each side of the connector a bit at a time until it comes out. Anyway, I’ve found once the 550 is installed, it’s reliable as any other motor.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I’ve found 550s to be pretty reliable. However, anything above a 15A current limit is likely to fail before a full season’s use and are also very sensitive to impacts and vibration. Bigger motors are generally stronger, and scaling laws play a significant role in their performance.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: In the application mentioned, where I’ve implemented a 20A limit—consistent with the MAXSwerve template—I haven’t encountered any problems. Other nearby teams also utilize MAXSwerve without issues. The only drawback I’ve noticed with MAXSwerve is that its motors are exposed, making them vulnerable to damage from other robots' intakes or attachments.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We’ve never burned any encoders, but we have removed the encoder wiring. Ideally, you’d want to replace the 550 with an integrated motor controller like the Kraken X44. However, doing so would likely be highly complex.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Replacing the motor would be quite difficult on MAX swerve. Everything below the Ultraplanetary system is custom hardware, and you would probably need to make your own. I’m not sure if the Ultraplanetary could handle a bigger motor.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
Two possibilities for adapting a motor to use an UltraPlanetary system exist, both requiring careful consideration. One approach involves modifying a NEO or SplineXS motor by trimming its shaft and reducing its diameter to accommodate a pinion adapter. A 3D-printed adapter would then connect the motor to the UltraPlanetary. While this method might work, it’s unconventional and may not be as robust as a direct connection. Another option is to build a custom gearbox that integrates a NEO or SplineXS motor with the steering gear, effectively replacing the UltraPlanetary entirely.

Alternatively, I would recommend purchasing a SwerveX2S system for a compact and powerful steering setup. While it’s possible to adapt the Maxswerve to use a non-550 steering motor, the process is complex, and there’s limited benefit unless you’re specifically aiming for a DIY project.

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked:
The pinions on a handful of them kept slipping, even after using a significant amount of loctite, meaning they would free-spin frequently, requiring us to disassemble the entire mechanism. The ultra-planetary mounting on the module also loosened quickly, though this may have been an error on our part.

From what others have shared, transitioning the turning motor into a non-550 configuration appears to be beyond my current capabilities. I appreciate all the helpful suggestions from those who contributed their insights!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: The friction-fit pinion, which should stay on without additional tools, is causing a manufacturing issue.

We've run our 550s at a 20-amp limit for three plus seasons, including those in our swerve modules, with absolutely no issues. There's little concern about burnout since the motors rarely stall, and even at 20 amps, you'd have plenty of time before a 550 would smoke if the wheels were to stall.

It’s also fairly easy to replace the encoder wires if you break them off—you just need a JST connector set, crimper, and soldering iron (though technically not necessary, but it makes the process much smoother). We even swapped one out during a match at our first competition after a falling coral landed onto one of our encoder wires.

posts.name: Xavier E.
posts.cooked: We’ve been using the MAXSwerve for three seasons now, but our main issues have been with the sensor wires from the motors and the encoder wire. This year, we switched to NEO Vortexes and SparkFlexes, which worked well for us. We were hoping REV would eventually upgrade the 550s to not require SparkMaxes, but that might still be something to consider for the future. While we don’t feel the 550s limit anything with the MAXSwerve, we’d appreciate the option to use another motor if needed.

Extremely importantly, retaining compound may work better than regular threadlocker for addressing shaft slippage issues. However, experiencing slippage on a 550 pinion sounds like a quality assurance problem, something that should be reported to REV if it continues to occur.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We pulled one set of motor sense wires from the motor; nothing remained to solder or crimp. We tossed that aside. Other sets of sense wires had been broken and repaired, mostly due to other robots getting into places we didn’t anticipate.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I've seen this issue with press-fit pulleys on Neo550s before. Retaining compounds can help, but the shaft is quite small, which ties into the idea that larger motors tend to be more robust.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: If I recall correctly, early neo550s had a quality issue related to shaft diameter or finish. The recommended fix involved using locktite or retaining compound.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Regardless of the quality issue, the Original Poster should contact REV to obtain replacement motors. They are really good about providing replacements for defects.
